ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText:
Composite bonding is a quick, non-invasive procedure that can transform your smile in just one visit.
Here’s exactly what to expect:



 CONSULTATION & SMILE ASSESSMENT 
Your journey starts with a detailed consultation with one of our cosmetic dentists, Dr. Roshni or Dr. Kim. We’ll assess your teeth, listen to your smile goals, and discuss whether composite bonding is the right treatment for you.
We may also take photos or do a digital smile preview.



SHADE MATCHING
We select a high-quality resin that matches the natural colour of your teeth perfectly.
If you plan to whiten your teeth, we recommend doing that before bonding so the resin can match your new shade.



TOOTH PREPARATION
The tooth surface is gently roughened and coated with a conditioning liquid to help the bonding material adhere properly.
No drilling or injections are usually needed.
Your natural tooth structure remains intact.



APPLICATION & COMPOSITE RESIN
The tooth-coloured resin is carefully applied, sculpted, and layered by hand.
 Our dentists shape it to correct chips, close gaps or reshape uneven teeth, all based on your facial balance.



CURING THE BONDING MATERIAL
Once the desired shape is achieved, the resin is hardened using a high-intensity curing light.
This process only takes a few seconds per tooth.



SHAPING & POLISHING
After curing, we refine the shape and polish the surface
 to give it a smooth, natural and glossy finish, indistinguishable from your real enamel.



FINAL CHECKS & SMILE REVEAL
We check your bite, comfort and symmetry.
You’ll be handed a mirror to see your new smile, and for most patients this is the moment the real transformation sinks in.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Composite bonding is a cosmetic dental treatment that uses a tooth-colored resin to reshape, rebuild, or perfect your teeth. It’s often used to fix chips, close small gaps, smooth out uneven edges, or make teeth look longer and more symmetrical. The resin is carefully sculpted by a dentist to match your natural teeth, then hardened with a special light. It’s a completely non-invasive procedure—no drills, no needles, no pain—and the results are instant. You walk in with a smile you’re self-conscious about, and walk out with one that feels like you. What makes composite bonding so popular is how simple and transformative it is. Unlike veneers, which require removing part of your tooth, bonding keeps your natural teeth fully intact. And unlike whitening, which may not work on all teeth or can fade quickly, bonding covers stains, wear, and imperfections with lasting results. With proper care, it can last up to 10 years and be easily touched up. It’s not about chasing perfection—it’s about feeling like your smile finally reflects who you are.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Composite bonding typically lasts 5 to 7 years, and with excellent care, it can last up to 10 years. Its longevity depends on factors like your oral hygiene, eating habits, and whether you grind your teeth or bite nails. Unlike veneers or crowns, bonding isn’t as durable, but it’s much less invasive—and it can be easily repaired or refreshed without replacing the whole tooth. Regular dental check-ups and avoiding things like hard sweets, coffee stains, or smoking can help your bonded smile look great for years.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: No, composite bonding is not painful—in fact, most people are surprised by how quick and comfortable it is. There’s no drilling, no needles, and no need for numbing in most cases. The dentist simply prepares the surface of your tooth, applies a tooth-colored resin, shapes it to perfection, and hardens it with a special light. It’s a totally non-invasive procedure, often completed in a single visit. You’ll be able to eat, talk, and smile right away—just with a lot more confidence.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: The cost of composite bonding typically ranges from £150 to £400 per tooth in the UK. The final price depends on several factors—like the dentist’s experience, the complexity of the work, and how many teeth you're having treated. For small touch-ups (like fixing a chip), it might be on the lower end. For full smile makeovers, it could cost £2,000–£4,000+, depending on how many teeth are bonded. The good news? Unlike more invasive options like veneers, composite bonding is more affordable, reversible, and often done in a single visit. And on Expert.One, you can compare and book the UK’s top-rated cosmetic dentists—without overpaying or compromising on skill.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Yes, composite bonding can absolutely fix gaps between teeth—and it’s one of the most popular reasons people choose it. A skilled dentist uses tooth-colored resin to carefully build out the sides of the teeth, closing the space in a way that looks completely natural. It’s quick, non-invasive, and doesn’t require braces, drilling, or tooth removal. In most cases, the gap can be closed in just one visit, with immediate, smile-ready results. It’s a simple fix with a big impact—especially when done by the right expert.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Composite bonding can improve the appearance of mildly crooked teeth, but it’s not a substitute for orthodontics in more severe cases. If your teeth are slightly rotated, uneven, or out of alignment, bonding can be used to reshape and balance them—making your smile look straighter without braces or aligners. The dentist applies a tooth-colored resin to smooth out edges, add volume where needed, and create a more symmetrical, aligned appearance. It’s quick, painless, and done in just one visit. However, if your teeth are significantly crowded or misaligned, you may need orthodontic treatment (like Invisalign) first, and then bonding for finishing touches. It’s best used for cosmetic refinement, not for major repositioning.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Yes, composite bonding can stain over time, but how much it stains depends on your habits and how well you care for it. The resin used in bonding is not as stain-resistant as natural enamel or porcelain, so things like coffee, tea, red wine, curry, and smoking can gradually cause discoloration—especially around the edges. However, the staining isn’t permanent and can often be polished away during routine dental visits, or refreshed with a simple touch-up. To keep your bonding looking its best, it helps to: Brush twice daily and flossAvoid or limit heavily pigmented foods and drinksRinse with water after mealsVisit your dentist regularly for cleanings and maintenanceWith proper care, composite bonding can stay looking fresh and natural for years.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Whether composite bonding is better than veneers depends on your goals, budget, and how permanent you want the results to be. Composite bonding is a great choice if you're looking for a quick, affordable, and non-invasive way to improve your smile. It’s ideal for fixing minor chips, small gaps, uneven edges, or discolouration. There’s no drilling or enamel removal, and it can usually be done in one visit. It’s also reversible and easier to adjust over time. Veneers, on the other hand, are more of a long-term investment. They’re custom-made, ultra-thin porcelain shells that are bonded to your teeth for a flawless, high-end result. They last longer—often 10 to 20 years—but require removing a small layer of enamel, which is permanent. Veneers are often the choice for those wanting a full smile makeover with maximum durability and polish. Both are excellent options, but the right one depends on how dramatic you want the change to be—and how permanent you want it.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Yes, composite bonding can stain over time. The resin material used isn’t as resistant to discoloration as natural tooth enamel or porcelain, so it can absorb pigments from things like coffee, tea, red wine, curry, and tobacco. However, staining can often be managed with good oral hygiene and regular dental cleanings, where your dentist can polish or refresh the bonding to restore its appearance. Avoiding or limiting heavily pigmented foods and habits helps keep your bonding looking fresh longer.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: ou can whiten your natural teeth after getting composite bonding, but it’s important to know that the bonding material won’t whiten like your real teeth do. Teeth whitening products work on natural enamel, but composite resin doesn’t respond to bleaching agents. This means your natural teeth can get lighter, but the bonded areas will stay the same shade. Because of that, many people choose to whiten their teeth before bonding to match the shade perfectly. If you whiten after bonding, you might need to have the bonding touched up or replaced to blend with your new tooth colour. If you’re thinking about whitening and bonding, it’s best to talk with your dentist to plan the timing for the best, most natural-looking results.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Composite bonding isn’t considered permanent, but it is long-lasting. With proper care, it typically lasts 5 to 10 yearsbefore needing repairs or replacement. Unlike veneers or crowns, bonding can wear down, chip, or stain over time because the resin material isn’t as strong as natural enamel. However, one of its benefits is that it can be easily repaired or refreshed without starting from scratch. So while it’s not permanent forever, it offers a durable, reversible way to improve your smile.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: The composite bonding procedure usually takes about 30 to 60 minutes per tooth. Because it’s a quick, minimally invasive treatment, many patients can have multiple teeth done in a single appointment. The dentist carefully prepares the tooth, applies and sculpts the resin, then hardens it with a special light—all without drilling or injections in most cases. So, whether it’s fixing a chip or closing gaps, you can expect to walk out with a transformed smile in just one visit.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: After getting composite bonding, it’s best to avoid habits and foods that can damage or stain the bonding material. Here’s what to watch out for: Hard or sticky foods like nuts, ice, hard candies, or chewing gum—these can chip or loosen the bonding.Biting your nails or chewing on pens—any pressure on the bonded teeth can cause damage.Staining substances such as coffee, tea, red wine, curry, and tobacco—they can discolor the resin over time.Grinding or clenching your teeth (if you do this, talk to your dentist about a night guard).Avoid using your bonded teeth as tools to open packages or bottles.Maintaining good oral hygiene and visiting your dentist regularly will help keep your bonded smile strong and looking fresh.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Yes, composite bonding is generally considered reversible. Since it usually involves minimal or no removal of your natural tooth enamel, the resin material can be removed or reshaped by a dentist without permanently altering the underlying tooth. This makes it a flexible option—you can have the bonding repaired, replaced, or even removed if you want a different look later on. However, if any enamel was removed during the process (which is rare with bonding), that part wouldn’t grow back. Overall, bonding offers a less permanent, more adjustable way to improve your smile compared to options like veneers.

ShortDescription: Transform your smile quickly and confidently with composite bonding.
ContentText: Yes, composite bonding can be easily repaired if it chips. Because the material is applied in layers, your dentist can quickly add more resin to the chipped area, reshape it, and cure it with a special light—all usually in a single visit. Repairing bonding is much simpler and less costly than replacing veneers or crowns, making it a convenient way to keep your smile looking flawless over time.

ContentText:
Foot and hand fungal infections can be more than just a cosmetic concern—they can be persistent, uncomfortable, and even painful if left untreated. These infections often cause the skin to crack, peel, itch, or become red and inflamed. In more severe cases, the nails may become thick, discoloured, brittle, and emit an unpleasant odour. Not only can this affect your confidence, but it can also lead to further complications such as spreading to other parts of the body or to others around you. Fungal infections thrive in warm, moist environments and can worsen over time, so early, professional treatment is key to restoring healthy skin and nails. Fungal nail infections can cause discolouration, thickening, brittleness, and discomfort in both fingernails and toenails.

You can now access highly effective treatments through Expert delivered by specialist doctors who are experienced in managing both fungal nails and related conditions such as ingrown toenails.  Treatment options include advanced laser therapy that penetrates deep into the nail to eliminate the infection, as well as expert fungal nail surgery for more severe cases. These tailored solutions are designed to restore healthy, clear nails and provide long-lasting relief.

What is Onchomycosisis?

Onchomycosisis is a fungal infection of the nail. It affects 10-30% of the global population and 3 in every 100 people in the UK. Then nail becomes deformed, overgrown and thick. The fungi enters under the nail and attacks both the underside of the nail plate and top keritonized layer of the nail bed. Debris called subungal hyperkeratosis accumulates under the nail plate. The viable fungi are located primarily in the debris and underside of the nail plate. The fungi are damaged when exposed to our Laser radiation. When the case is serious then removal of the nail is required and this is carried out by a surgeon. 

What are the symptoms?

The nail can become thickened and discoloured. It can turn white, black, yellow or green. It can have poor cosmetic appearance and very embarassing. Sometimes fungal infections can result in pain in the toes and fingertips. Sometimes the fungus can emit a slight odour.

Walking barefoot in damp shoes and socks that prevent ventilation.

Medical conditions such as diabetes and aids. In fact any illenss that supresses the immune system increases the risk of fungal nail infection.

The duration of Invisalign treatment varies significantly depending on the complexity of your dental alignment and the specific goals of your treatment plan. At Expert, they use advanced 3D scans and digital treatment planning tools to provide an accurate estimate before you even begin.

General Timeframes

Mild Corrections:
For minor crowding, small gaps, or slight misalignments, treatment can take as little as 3 to 6 months. These cases usually involve fewer aligners and require less complex tooth movement.

Moderate Corrections:
For more noticeable spacing issues, moderate crowding, or mild bite problems, the average treatment time is typically 6 to 12 months.

Complex Corrections:
For cases involving significant bite correction (such as overbite, underbite, crossbite) or severe crowding, treatment can range from 12 to 24 months. In some highly complex situations, treatment might extend slightly beyond 24 months, though this is rare.

The duration of Invisalign treatment varies significantly depending on the complexity of your dental alignment and the specific goals of your treatment plan. At Expert, they use advanced 3D scans and digital treatment planning tools to provide an accurate estimate before you even begin.

General Timeframes

Mild Corrections:
For minor crowding, small gaps, or slight misalignments, treatment can take as little as 3 to 6 months. These cases usually involve fewer aligners and require less complex tooth movement.

Moderate Corrections:
For more noticeable spacing issues, moderate crowding, or mild bite problems, the average treatment time is typically 6 to 12 months.

Complex Corrections:
For cases involving significant bite correction (such as overbite, underbite, crossbite) or severe crowding, treatment can range from 12 to 24 months. In some highly complex situations, treatment might extend slightly beyond 24 months, though this is rare.

The Plasma Pen uses an electrical arching device, which delivers heat energy into the skin without actually touching it. The discharge of the current leaves micro craters in the skin. This trauma helps to stimulate the skin’s regeneration process, which enables it to restore its natural elasticity, achieving a firm and tight result.

Is the treatment suitable for me?

It is suitable for you if you want a non-surgical tightening treatment of the face or body, whether it’s getting rid of loose skin or removing fine lines and wrinkles. However, it is not recommended for dark skin as it can lead to risk of post inflammatory hyper-pigmentation.

How many sessions do I need?

You will see significant improvement after your first session, although some clients may need to attend a further session. You will need to give the skin enough time to heal before you have a second session. Normally one to two sessions are sufficient to achieve optimal results.

Is there any downtime?

The skin will have multiple small trauma spots, which will be visible at first. These will turn into dark scabs. These are part of the healing process and can take up to two weeks to fall off. It’s normal to have some swelling of the areas for up to a week, accompanied with the scabbing. Once the scabs fall off you may have some hyper-pigmentation. This will fade over the next few months.

Results

The results are amazing. Loose skin will be tightened or eliminated. Results are immediate, but the final results are normally seen a few months after the treatment, when skin has been fully restored and the collagen formation process has started.
